feed.title: Algorithmic Composition
feed.subtitle: Notes for Summer School Seminar @ IU AVARTS 2017/06

entry.title: Overview
entry.content:
Topics

  • Introduction
  • History and Principles
  • Client and Server programs in sound synthesis
  • Syntax and Semantics in programming languages
  • Unit Generators in sound synthesis
  • Writing SynthDefs (Synthesis Patches)
  • Using Patterns (Musical Event score generators)
  • Live control with OSC and MIDI
  • Randomness and Chaos
  • Data driven sound synthesis

Exercises

Server, OSC, Synth, Node, Bus, Buffer

  • Find a way to list all servers declared by the system in the Server class.
  • Create a Synth
  • List the current node tree of the default server on the post window
  • Explain the structure of the node tree of the default server.
  • Load a buffer from a sound file in supercollider. Find its number and its frame size and number of audio channels. Play the file in supercollider
  • Busses:
    • Control busses
      • Create a control-rate bus.
      • Write to it using a control-rate ugen.
      • Map a control
    • Audio busses
    • Multichannel expansion

Unit Generators, SynthDefs, MouseX/Y, Envelopes.

  • Map the output range of a Unit Generator's signal to the range from 2 to 25 in two different ways:
    • By modifying the corresponding parameters already built-in the Unit Generator.
    • By using a single linear mapping method applied to the Unit Generator.
  • Create a SynthDef with two control inputs, and code this to create the control inputs in two different ways:
    • Implicitly
    • Explicitly
  • Answers
    • Explicit
    • Implicit
      • Control one parameter of a synth with mouse x (horizontally) and another parameter with mouse y (vertically)
      • Define a SynthDef that uses a percussive envelope and create synths of different durations from it

Synthesis Techniques

Non-sample based

  • Demonstrate additive synthesis of tones with a small number of sinusoidal components
  • Demonstrate additive synthesis using wavetables and sinusoids (Blip)
  • Answer 1: Simple Wavetable
  • Answer 2: Blip
    • Demonstrate use of Delay
    • Use a Comb Filter to generate pitched sound signals
    • Demonstrate use of Hi-pass, low-pass, band-pass and band-reject filters
    • Use Formants to generate sounds resembling human vocalisation
  • from http://sccode.org/1-4WS
  • Deconstructing the central formant synthesis function from above example
  • from http://sccode.org/1-4Vq

Sample based

  • PlayBuf
  • BufRd
  • DiskIn
  • Granular Synthesis Ugens and techniques

Spectral processing (FFT/IFFT, spectral manipulations).

  • FFT/IFFT
  • PV-UGens

Chaotic and Noise Generators

Control Structures

Demonstrate use of the following:

  • Conditionals
  • Loops
  • Iteration over Collections
  • Branching
  • Choice
  • Explicit Evaluation of Functions, Function Callback, Asynchronous Control

Data Structures

  • Scalar data elements: Magnitude, Integer, Float, Symbol
  • Collections:
    • Sequenceable: String, Array, List, Signal
    • Indexable by Key: Dictionary, IdentityDictionary, Event
    • Non-Indexable: Set
  • Generative and Lazy Data Structures: Stream, Interval
  • Data Storage on Disc

GUI construction

  • Create a bank of sliders
  • Create a button that starts and stops a synth

MIDI

  • MIDIFunc

(also: Obsolete MIDI classes)

OSC

  • OSCFunc

(Also: Obsolete OSC Classes)

Routines, Scheduling

Events, Patterns, Streams, Tempo

Physical Computing

Data Driven Synthesis
entry.summary:
Topics

  • Introduction
  • History and Principles
  • Client and Server programs in sound synthesis
  • Syntax and Semantics in programming languages
  • Unit Generators in sound synthesis
  • Writing SynthDefs (Synthesis Patches)
  • Using Patterns (Musical Event score generators)
  • Live control with OSC and MIDI
  • Randomness and Chaos
  • Data driven sound synthesis

entry.title: History and Principles
entry.content:
Algorithmic Composition before computers

First Computer Programs for Writing Music

First Analog and Digital Synthesisers

Music-N Languages

Interpreted Languages

GUI based control

Current Trends
entry.summary: Algorithmic Composition before computers

entry.title: Introduction
entry.content:
Algorithms

Definition of Algorithm

An algorithm is a recipe, method, or technique for doing something. The essential feature of an algorithm is that it is made up of a finite set of rules or operations that are unambiguous and simple to follow (computer scientists use technical terms for these two properties: definite and effective, respectively). It is obvious from this definition that the notion of an algorithm is somewhat imprecise, a feature it shares with all foundational mathematical ideas—for instance, the idea of a set.

(Wilson and Keil 1999: 11)

Example of Algorithm and Programming Language

(Semantics and Syntax)

Thomas Fink: List of Tie Knots http://www.tcm.phy.cam.ac.uk/~tmf20/tieknots.shtml

Example of Algorithms an Graphic Notation symbols: Genjimon

http://viewingjapaneseprints.net/texts/topictexts/artist_varia_topics/genjimon7.html

The "Genji-mon" (源氏紋) or "Genji-Kô" (源氏香) symbols used for the 54 chapters of the Tale of Genji (early Japanese "novel"). They indicate the possible groupings and subgroupings of five elements, from no element being grouped together with any other element (chapter 2) to all five elements joined in a single grouping (chapter 53), and everything in between. In the notation used in the chapter symbols, elements which are under a common horizontal bar are grouped together – except that where a vertical stem crosses a horizontal bar (as opposed to a corner or "T"), this does not indicate a grouping. So the symbols for chapters 35 and 42 (shown in red in the diagram) both indicate the same grouping: elements 1, 2, and 4 in one subgroup, elements 3 and 5 in another subgroup. The 52 possible 5-element subgroupings were expanded to 54 (the number of chapters in the Tale of Genji) by using equivalent representations for chapters 35 and 42, and by adding a special symbol for chapter 54 (shown in green in the diagram). In the incense-distinguishing game (see en:Kōdō#Kumikō), apparently the chapter 1 symbol takes the place of the chapter 35 symbol, while the chapter 54 symbol is dropped (see Genjikonozu.PNG), leaving one symbol for each of the 52 possible groupings (52 is a Bell number).

(from: )

Algorithms and parametrization or abstraction

Origins and role of algorithms

Algorithms and Mathematics

Algorithms and Design

Algorithms and Data

Composition

  • Composition vs Construction vs Design
  • Generative Design and Generative Music Creation

Algorithms

Definition of Algorithm

An algorithm is a recipe, method, or technique for doing something. The essential feature of an algorithm is that it is made up of a finite set of rules or operations that are unambiguous and simple to follow (computer scientists use technical terms for these two properties: definite and effective, respectively). It is obvious from this definition that the notion of an algorithm is somewhat imprecise, a feature it shares with all foundational mathematical ideas—for instance, the idea of a set.

(Wilson and Keil 1999: 11)
